column1: Comments

Alright knucklehead, China built more solar in just the last year than the **entire US installed solar capacity**.

They've now cornered the global market on solar and have a massive export industry.

Biden's infrastructure plan gave the US clean tech industry a shot in the arm, but smooth brains like you are still clinging to "drill baby drill".

I was referring to this where France opposed any increase in fuel taxes: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellow_vests_protests

I suppose they are still better equipped to reduce emissions out of most Western countries, but in their case they decided that wealth inequality was as or more important to tackle first. Which I completely understand. 

I used to think that the Citizen‚Äôs Climate Lobby was the best shot for the US getting their shit together. Maybe it still is, but with the current US political landscape there is absolutely no way it‚Äôs going to happen. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_Climate_Lobby

Alright Greta, US 3,809,525 sq mi,  UK  94,354 sq mi. Size matters, we have climates from perma-frost to death valley. I'm not peddling my fat ass to work while China burns the fuck out of coal and oil across the world. That's some Bubba Gump intelligence.
so...war it is...

Thanks for typing that out, but my goal wasn't to pack a precise and nuanced economic treatise in those two sentences, that's not the normal standard for reddit comments in WSB, just pointing out that we're currently running a massive fiscal stimulus via government spending, which is similar in many ways to what WW2 did in terms of stimulating the economy. Because of the debt, WW2 was followed by huge currency devaluations/lowering the peg against gold. I think it has a lot of similarities to that scenario, but spending on infrastructure and bond holders rather than weapons factories. The IRA is a *huge* investment. The Loan Program Office alone has loan authority of like $400B for clean energy projects.

Besides pure materiel, a lot of the wartime spending went toward things that helped with industrial production afterwards, it's not that different in terms of trying to spur growth.
She should be more specific. 8.6 trillion plus one head of a billionaire on a stake each year for sacrifice. It‚Äôs mostly preventative. 1 less yacht from setting sail each week.

China has the most coal-fired power plants in the world, with 1,142 operational plants on the Chinese mainland as of July 2023. China is also responsible for building the majority of new coal power plants globally, accounting for 95% of new construction in 2023. This was 19 times more than the rest of the world's construction, and China's 47.4 GW of new coal power capacity accounted for two-thirds of the global increase in operating capacity. Via Carbon Brief. Biden can do what he wants we can live by candlelight and shit in holes and we'll never erase what they're doing Globally. So yeah, it's a pipe dream until everyone is on board with their checkbook.
France is like 80% nuclear tho

I guess I was trying to say that a $15k BYD car at 0% APR for 24mo would make waves in the market. That's why we're keeping them out. 

They'd pull some loss-leader strat fuckery and flood the EV market with cheap EVs that aren't state/fed subsidized. Cars in that price range with low ball financing could cripple US autos.

That won't work.  Switching to cash isn't instantaneous, it's next trading day.  You'll be flagged ptd and can't go back unless you close at 25K or still have your one get of jail free card.
They‚Äôre called instant deposits. Depends on your balance usually between 1k-5K but can be much higher depending on your portfolio

I‚Äôve switched my margin account to cash to bypass the day trading rule over 10 times and never had an issue. While you have the trade you can switch the account and close the trade with no penalty. After about 5 trading days you can switch back to margin. And should you be in this type of situation again you can do it again. Never been flagged and actually did it again last week cause I wanted to close a day trade on $QQQ.

You sound like you have a ton of money if you were able to recover $55k by trading shares of AAPL and NVDA after losing $86k. OP put his life savings into this so I don't think he has another $100k lying around to play with
Ouch! Time to rebuild brother one day at a time and work on your trading discipline!
MACD/RSI for the buy trigger on a reversal, it's a classic strategy. Look at different timeframes first and read the charts, then you just gotta pray it moves enough to make some money.
Now you know how you got to the 40k- hard work- just keep stacking and learn from your mistakes.

Lost $80k trading options on Webull (over 18 months... learning, trading and gambling), took a break for a few months, then opened a RH account with only $1000 (blew that 5 times...down $5900). Stopped trading options and started trading shares (i.e. buying $AAPL $NVDA on big dips)... I've since made back $55k and life is great. There's hope, but stay away from options. ;) ...I only come back to WSB as a reminder to not trade options. Keep ya head up!

Of course, I've cut my losses many times. Only by manually trading out, not via stop-loss. I've also held some bags. Those things are almost inevitable. I don't trade options or penny stocks. The large cap stocks typically do not go bankrupt overnight (and even if they did, stop loss won't help for overnight crashes). It is perfectly possible to invest (not daytrade) without stop-loss.
